title: Protocol for the preparation of site-specific succinylated histone mimics to investigate the impact on nucleosome dynamics

Step-by-step method details
Synthesis of tert-butyl N-vinyl succinamate (compound 1)
Timing: 3 days
Synthesis of mono-tert-butyl succinate (Step i in Scheme 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch1]) (Colombo et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2])
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/728-Sch1.jpg
Scheme 1. Synthesis of tert-butyl N-vinyl succinamate
Dissolve succinic anhydride (3.00 g, 29.98 mmol), N-hydroxysuccinimide (0.3 eq, 1.04 g, 8.99 mmol), and DMAP (0.1 eq, 366.25 mg, 3.00 mmol) in 40 mL toluene.
Add triethylamine (0.3 eq, 910.07 mg, 8.99 mmol) and tert-butyl alcohol (2.0 eq, 4.44 g, 59.96 mmol) into the mixture.
Reflux the mixture for 24 h and let it cool to 25°C.
Wash the upper organic phase with 1 M HCl solution and followed with brine.
Dry the organic phase over Na2SO4 (s), filter, and concentrate under vacuum to give the crude product.
Purify the crude product in a flash chromatography column eluted with 9:1 DCM/acetone to afford the product as a yellow oil (4.2 g, 24.11 mmol, 80% yield).
Analyze the product by 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 2.63 (t, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H), 2.54 (t, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H), 1.44 (s, 9H).
Note: Mono-tert-butyl succinate is commercially available (Sigma, cat#547352).
Synthesis of tert-butyl succinamate (Step ii in Scheme 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch1]) (Grimm and Lavis, 2011[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]).
Dissolve mono-tert-butyl succinate (500 mg, 2.87 mmol), NH4Cl (3.0 eq, 460.59 mg, 8.61 mmol), EDCI (1.5 eq, 825.38 mg, 4.31 mmol), and HOBt (1.5 eq, 659.35 mg, 4.31 mmol) in 10 mL DMF.
Add DIEA (1.5 eq, 556.47 mg, 4.31 mmol) into the mixture above.
After stirring for 6 h at 25°C, pour the reaction solution into 30 mL saturated NaHCO3 solution and extract with ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL).
Wash the combined organic layers with brine, dry over Na2SO4, filter, and concentrate under vacuum.

Purify the crude product in a flash chromatography column eluted with 9:1 DCM/MeOH to afford tert-butyl succinamate as a clear oil (497.18 mg, 2.87 mmol, 100% yield).
Analyze the product by 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 6.43 (s, 1H), 6.30 (s, 1H), 2.39 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 2.32 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 1.27 (s, 9H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 174.18, 171.63, 79.94, 29.85, 29.60, 27.31; HRMS (EI): calculated for C8H15NO3 (M+): 173.1052, found 173.1057.
Synthesis of tert-butyl N-vinyl succinamate (Step iii in Scheme 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch1]) (Compound 1) (Hansen and Skrydstrup, 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]).
Dissolve tert-butyl succinamate (100 mg, 0.577 mmol), Cs2CO3 (1.0 eq, 188.10 mg, 0.577 mmol), CuI (0.2 eq, 21.99 mg, 0.115 mmol), vinyl iodide (0.8 eq, 71.10 mg, 0.462 mmol), and N1,N2-dimethylethane-1,2-diamine (0.4 eq, 20.36 mg, 0.230 mmol) in 5 mL anhydrous THF.
Stir the reaction mixture for 17 h at 70°C under argon protection.
Filter the reaction mixture and concentrate the filtrate under vacuum to afford the crude product.
Purify the crude product in a flash chromatography column eluted with 50:50 hexane/ethyl acetate to afford Compound 1 as a yellow oil (60 mg, 301.13 μmol, 52% yield).
Analyze the product by 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.02 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 1H), 6.91 (m, 1H), 4.56 (dd, J = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 4.33 (dd, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 2.53 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H), 2.44 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H), 1.37 (s, 9H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 172.22, 169.61, 128.65, 95.30, 80.93, 30.91, 30.46, 27.97; HRMS (EI): calculated for C10H17NO3 (M+): 199.1208, found 199.1199.
Preparation of recombinant Xenopus laevis histones
Timing: 2 weeks

Wild type histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 are expressed in Escherichia coli Rosetta strain (DE3) and purified as previously described (Luger et al., 1999[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]).
Grow E. coli Rosetta cells harboring pET-histone expression plasmids in 1 L LB media containing ampicillin and chloramphenicol at 37°C until OD600 reaches 0.8.
Induce protein expression by adding isopropyl β-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) to a final concentration of 0.6 mM and incubate for 4 h at 37°C.
Collect the cells by centrifugation at 3,500 × g for 25 min at 4°C.
Resuspend the cells in lysis buffer (25 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, 1 M NaCl, 1 mM PMSF, pH 7.5).
Critical: For the lysis buffer, 1 mM PMSF is added just before use as it hydrolyses rapidly.
Sonicate the cells (5 s ON, 10 s OFF, 30 min) and collect the pellet of the inclusion bodies containing the corresponding histone proteins by centrifugation at 4°C (12,000 × g, 15 min).
Resuspend the pellet in 15 mL lysis buffer containing 1% (v/v) Triton X-100 and centrifuge at 12,000 × g for 15 min at 4°C, and then pour off the supernatant.
Repeat step f twice and then wash the pellet twice with 15 mL lysis buffer. After final wash, pour off the supernatant.
Add 250 μL DMSO to the pellet and incubate for 20 min at 25°C.
Add 5 mL HU-500 buffer (6 M Urea, 25 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, 500 mM NaCl, pH 7.5) to the mixture.
Add HU-0 buffer (6 M Urea, 25 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, pH 7.5) to the mixture to dilute the salt concentration to 100 mM with shaking.
Keep shaking and mixing for another 2 h at 25°C.

Centrifuge at 20,000 × g for 10 min at 25°C (Note: Most of the pellet should be dissolved in the HU buffer).
Collect the supernatant and load onto a HiTrap SP HP column (5 mL, GE) pre-equilibrated with HU-100 buffer (6 M Urea, 25 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, 100 mM NaCl, pH 7.5).
Elute histone proteins with a gradient of 0%–100% HU-500 buffer over 25 min at a flow rate of 2 mL/min.
Analyze the peak fractions by 18% SDS-PAGE and pool the fractions containing the purified histone proteins.
Load the combined fractions onto a HiLoad 16/60 Superdex 200 pg size-exclusion column (GE) pre-equilibrated with HU-1000 buffer (6 M Urea, 25 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, 1000 mM NaCl, pH 7.5).
Elute histone proteins using 100% HU-1000 buffer at a flow rate of 2 mL/min.
Analyze the peak fractions by 18% SDS-PAGE and collect the corresponding fractions.
Dialyze the histone proteins against dd H2O containing 2 mM DTT at 4°C (at least three changes).
Freeze dry the protein solution to obtain the lyophilized histone powder.
Note: Purification of mutated histone H2B K34C will be the same as the preparation of wild type histones.
Pause Point: Purified histone proteins can be stored at −80°C for an indefinite length of time.
Preparation of modified histone H2BKc34succ-tBu
Timing: 3 days
The ‘thiol-ene’ coupling reaction of Compound 1 with mutated histone H2BK34C followed by HPLC purification generates the modified histone H2BKc34succ-tBu (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A) (Li et al., 2011[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/728-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Installation of the succinyl lysine analog onto recombinant histone
(A) Scheme for the installation of the succinyl lysine analog (Kcsucc) at position 34 of histone H2B.

(B and C) LC-MS and deconvolution results for the thiol-ene coupling product H2BKc34succ-tBu (B) and the deprotected final product H2BKc34succ (C). Figure reprinted with permission from Jing et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6].
The ‘thiol-ene’ coupling reaction:
Dissolve mutated histone H2BK34C in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.0) containing 6 M Gdn·HCl to a final concentration of 1 mM.
Add DTT to a final concentration of 5 mM.
Critical: DTT stock solution (1 M) should be freshly prepared.
Add 50 equivalent (50 mM) of compound 1 into the reaction mixture.
Add VA-044 (20 mM) and dimethyl sulfide (100 mM) separately into the reaction mixture.
Initiate the reaction by incubating the reaction tube in a 42°C water bath.
Critical: Normally, the ‘thiol-ene’ coupling reaction completes in 2 h.
Analyze the reaction by LC-MS using a Vydac 218TP C4 column (4.6 mm × 250 mm, Grace Davison) and ESI-MS. The mobile phase is HPLC buffer A and HPLC buffer B. The deconvolution results are obtained using the UniDec software.
HPLC purification of the modified histone:
After the reaction finishes according to the HPLC analysis (histone H2BK34C should be fully converted to the modified histone H2BKc34succ-tBu), load the reaction mixture onto a semi-prep column (Vydac C4 column, Grace Davison).
Elute modified histone with a gradient of 20%–50% HPLC buffer B over 35 min.
Analyze the peak fractions by ESI-MS and obtain the deconvolution results of each peak in the UniDec software (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Pool the fractions containing the pure modified histones, followed by lyophilization.
Pause Point: Purified histone proteins can be stored at −80°C for an indefinite length of time.
Deprotection of the tert-butyl group on histone H2BKc34succ-tBu
Timing: 2 days
The tert-butyl group on histone H2BKc34succ-tBu is deprotected by treating the intermediate protein with TFA, followed by HPLC purification and lyophilization (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).

Deprotection reaction in 70% TFA:
Dissolve the intermediate protein H2BKc34succ-tBu in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.0) containing 6 M Gdn·HCl to a final concentration of 5 mM.
Keep the above protein solution on ice.
Add TFA dropwise to the reaction mixture to a final concentration of 70% (v/v).
Incubate the reaction at 25°C with shaking.
Monitor the reaction by LC-MS using a Vydac 218TP C4 column (4.6 mm × 250 mm, Grace Davison) and ESI-MS. The mobile phase is HPLC buffer A and HPLC buffer B. The deconvolution results are obtained using the UniDec software.
HPLC purification of deprotected histone:
After the reaction finishes according to the HPLC analysis (the intermediate protein H2BKc34succ-tBu should be fully deprotected), remove the TFA under a stream of compressed argon.
Load the reaction mixture onto a semi-prep column (Vydac C4 column, Grace Davison) and elute deprotected histone with a gradient of 20%–50% HPLC buffer B over 35 min.
Analyze the peak fractions by ESI-MS and obtain the deconvolution results of each peak using the UniDec software (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Pool the fractions containing the pure deprotected histones, followed by lyophilization.
Pause Point: Purified histone proteins can be stored at −80°C for an indefinite length of time.
Preparation of histone H2A-H2B dimers and (H3-H4)2 tetramers
Timing: 2 days
H2A-H2B dimers and (H3-H4)2 tetramers are prepared by histone refolding (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]) (Luger et al., 1999[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/728-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. The elution profile of H2A-H2B dimers and (H3-H4)2 tetramers in the gel-filtration chromatography detected at 280 nm
H2A-H2B dimers eluted out at around 16 mL, according to its molecular weight (26 kD), whereas (H3-H4)2 tetramers eluted out at around 14.1 mL, according to its molecular weight (53 kD). The purity and stoichiometry of the fractions were verified by 18% SDS-PAGE.
Preparation of H2A-H2B dimers:

Mix equal molar quantities of H2A and H2B proteins in histone unfolding buffer (6 M Gdn·HCl, 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1.0 mM EDTA, 10 mM DTT) to a final histone concentration of 1 mg/mL.
Incubate the mixture for 30 min on ice.
Dialyze the mixture in histone refolding buffer (2 M NaCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1.0 mM EDTA, 5 mM β-mercaptoethanol) for 4 h at 4°C, and then change the histone refolding buffer and dialyze for another 16 h.
Concentrate the refolded dimer solution using an Amicon® Ultra 15 mL centrifugal filter device (Membrane nominal molecular weight limit, 3 kDa) to less than 1 mL.
Critical: When performing concentration with the centrifugal filter device, do not concentrate the total volume below 200 μL, or it may result in precipitation.
Load the concentrated mixture onto a HiLoad 16/60 Superdex 200 pg column (GE) pre-equilibrated with histone refolding buffer to remove any histone monomers and impurities.
Elute histone proteins with histone refolding buffer over 25 min at a flow rate of 1 mL/min.
Analyze the peak fractions by 18% SDS-PAGE to verify the quality of the purified dimers and pool the corresponding fractions.
Concentrate the pooled fractions using an Amicon® Ultra 15 mL centrifugal filter device (Membrane nominal molecular weight limit, 3 kDa).
For long-term storage, dialyze the concentrated fraction in storage buffer (2 M NaCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1 mM EDTA, 5 mM β-mercaptoethanol, 50% glycerol).
Determine the protein concentration of the assembled H2A-H2B dimers by Bradford Protein Assay kit.
Store the assembled H2A-H2B dimers at −20°C.
Use the same method to prepare H2A-H2BKc34succ dimers and (H3-H4)2 tetramers.
Pause Point: Purified histone dimers and tetramers can be stored at −20°C for up to 4 months.
Preparation and purification of fluorophore-labeled mononucleosomes
Timing: 2 days

Histone dimers and tetramers can be assembled into nucleosomes using salt deposition (Luger et al., 1997[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/728-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Schematics for the stepwise salt dialysis method to reconstitute nucleosomes
The quality and compaction of reconstituted nucleosomes were analyzed by Native-PAGE.
Stepwise salt dialysis:
Determine the protein concentration of the assembled histone dimers (modified H2A-H2BKc34succ dimers or unmodified H2A-H2B dimers) and (H3-H4)2 tetramers by Bradford Protein Assay kit.
Determine the concentration of fluorophore-labeled DNA by a UV-Vis spectrophotometer (A260 nm, NanoDrop 2000, Thermo).
Mix the purified histone dimers (modified H2A-H2BKc34succ dimers or unmodified H2A-H2B dimers) and (H3-H4)2 tetramers with the fluorophore-labeled “Widom 601” DNA (at a molar ratio of dimer : tetramer : DNA = 2 : 1 : 1.2) to a concentration of 2 μM in 50 μL reconstitution buffer (2 M KCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8, 0.1 mM EDTA).
Critical: Test the ratio of dimer, tetramer, and DNA at a much lower concentration (∼30 nM in 30 μL) to confirm nucleosome formation so as not to waste components on a large preparation.
Transfer the mixture into a Slide-A-Lyzer MINI dialysis unit (Thermo) and sequentially dialyze at 4°C against reconstitution buffer containing 1.6 M KCl, 1.4 M KCl, 1.2 M KCl, 1.0 M KCl, 0.8 M KCl, 0.5 M KCl, and 0.2 M KCl for 50 min each, followed by 10 mM KCl 12 h.
Pause Point: The final dialysis step in 10 mM KCl is left to proceed 12 h.
Check the quality and compaction of the reconstituted nucleosomes by Native-PAGE (5% TBE gel, acrylamide : Bis = 29 : 1).
Stain the gel with ethidium bromide (EB) for 15 min and visualize the nucleosomes under UV using a MyECL Imager system (Thermo Fisher Scientific).
Purification of reconstituted nucleosomes:

Concentrate the reconstitution mixture to 75 μL using an EMD Millipore Amicon Ultra Centrifugal Filter (Cat#UFC500324, 3 kDa Ultracel, 0.5 mL).
Add 25 μL native loading buffer (62.5 mM Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 40% glycerol, 0.01% Bromophenol Blue) into the concentrated mixture.
Purify the reconstituted nucleosomes by Native-PAGE (5% TBE gel, acrylamide : Bis = 60 : 1) using a mini prep cell (Mini Prep Cell, Bio-Rad 1702908). The elutant is monitored by a UV spectrometer (ÄKTA pure protein purification system). Elution buffer contains 10 mM KCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, 10% glycerol, pH 7.8, 0.1 mM EDTA and running buffer contains 0.2× TBE.
Analyze the peak fractions by Native-PAGE (5 % TBE gel, acrylamide : Bis = 29 : 1) and pool the corresponding fractions.
The purity of the purified nucleosomes is verified by Native-PAGE (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).

Figure 4. The final purified nucleosomes (unmodified and H2BKc34succ, as indicated) used in the FRET experiments
After purification, the amount of free DNA was significantly reduced. Figure reprinted with permission from Jing et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6].
Concentrate the purified nucleosomes using an Amicon® Ultra 15 mL centrifugal filter device (Membrane nominal molecular weight limit, 3 kDa).
Determine the concentration of the purified nucleosomes by UV-Vis spectrophotometer (A260 nm, NanoDrop 2000, Thermo).
Store the purified nucleosomes at 4°C until use.
Note: Purified nucleosomes can be stored at 4°C for up to 1 week.
Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) analysis of nucleosome dynamics
Timing: 4 h
Salt-dependent dissociation of mononucleosomes can be quantified by a single-pair FRET-based approach as described in the literature (Bohm et al., 2011[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1], Gansen et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]). The donor and acceptor fluorophores used here are Alexa Fluor 488 (excitation at 490 nm and emission at 525 nm) and Alexa Fluor 594 (excitation at 590 nm and emission at 617 nm), respectively.

FRET sample preparation:
Determine the concentration of the purified nucleosomes by UV-Vis spectrophotometer (A260 nm, NanoDrop 2000, Thermo).
Dilute the purified nucleosomes in the elution buffer to a final concentration at 1 ng/μL nucleosome.
Critical: Do not vortex during the FRET sample preparation step. Use a pipette to homogenize the mixture.
Prepare the series of experimental buffers using FRET low salt buffer (10 mM NaCl, 10 mM Tris, 0.1 mM EDTA, pH 7.5, 1 mM ascorbic acid, 0.1 g/L BSA) and FRET high salt buffer (2 M NaCl, 10 mM Tris, 0.1 mM EDTA, pH 7.5, 1 mM ascorbic acid, 0.1 g/L BSA) at different salt concentrations from 0.01 M to 1.6 M (190 μL per sample).
Add 10 μL diluted nucleosome solution into each experimental buffer (final total volume for each sample is 200 μL).

Incubate the samples in a 384-well microplate (50 μL/well, 3 replicates for each sample) for 5 min at 25°C.
FRET measurements:
Use a plate reader (Beckman Coulter, DTX 880) to measure fluorescence intensity in each well. Energy transfer changes due to salt-induced nucleosome dissociation can be measured by the emission of the acceptor (Alexa 594) upon donor excitation (Alexa 488). Fluorescence is detected in two spectral windows to yield the signal intensities of the donor (   I D 0   ) and transfer (   I T 0   ) channels.
FRET data processing and analysis:
Correct the intensity of donor (   I D   ) and transfer (   I T   ) using the following equations:
   I T  =  (   I T 0  −   B T   )  −   a  D T    (   I D 0  −   B D   )  −   f  d i r    
   I D  =  (   I D 0  −  B D   )

Where,   B T    and    B D    are background intensities of the experimental buffer,    a  D T     is the spectral crosstalk from the donor to the transfer channel, and    f  d i r     is the direct excitation of the acceptor dye. The formula for calculating    a  D T     and    f  d i r     is described in Gansen et al. (Gansen et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]).
The FRET intensity (IF) is a measure of energy transfer efficiency and is calculated using the following equation:
  FRET intensity   (  I F  )  =   I T    I T  +   I D     
Input the data into OriginPro 8 using salt concentration as the x-axis and FRET intensity as the y-axis. To measure the salt-dependent dissociation of the mononucleosomes, fit the following sigmoidal function to the experimental curve:
   I F   ( X )  =  I F   ( 0 )  +     I F   ( ∞ )  −  I F   ( 0 )    1 + exp  (  c  1 / 2   −  X )  / b     
Stability of the mononucleosomes is quantified by the    c  1 / 2     parameter and is the salt concentration where the intensity (Y axis) has dropped to half its initial value. Here, X is the salt concentration in M and b describes the slope of the curve at X =    c  1 / 2    .    I F    (0) and    I F    (  ∞  ) are the amplitude and offset of the salt-titration curve.
